bibl.title: A Lamp for the Path and Commentary
bibl.author: Sherburne, Richard

sentence.phrase: Atīśa’s Lamp for the Path to Enlightenment
I pay homage to the ever-youthful Mañjuśrī!
I bow in great reverence to all the Conquerors of the three times,
To their Teachings, and the Spiritual Community.
I shall light a Lamp for the Path to Enlightenment,
At the request of my good disciple Jang-chup-ö (byang chub 'od).
Since they are Low, Middling, or Great,
Persons should be understood as three:
The characteristics of these are very clear, and
I shall note the individual divisions.
Those who seek for their own sake
The mere pleasures of cyclic existence,
By whatsoever techniques,
They are to be known as low persons.
Whosoever seeks mere their own peace,
[They who] have turned their backs on the pleasures of worldly existence,
And have turned away from ethical transgressions,
These persons are called “middling”.
Whosoever thoroughly wishes
To extinguish thoroughly all sufferings of others
[Through inference of such] by way of the suffering
Which is included in their own continuum, that person is supreme.
For those holy beings whose desire
Is for the highest of Enlightenments,
I shall explain the right means
Which were taught to me by my Gurus.
Facing a painted image of the Perfect Buddha,
A holy reliquary and so forth,
Make offerings of flowers and incense
And whatever objects may be at hand.
Then with the Sevenfold Worship which is expressed
In the Deeds of Samantabhadra,
And a mind that does not turn back until
[One] reaches the Heart of Enlightenment,
With great faith in the Three Jewels,
Touching a bent knee to the ground,
And with folded hands
First go for refuge three times.
Then, because a mind of love for
All sentient beings is a prerequisite,
One observes transmigrators — without exception —
Who are suffering because of death and migration and so forth, and
[Because of] being born in the three bad migrations, etc.
By [seeing] that suffering, [one] suffers;
And, by reason of [having seen] such suffering of suffering,
He who wishes to liberate transmigrators
Should generate a Mind of Enlightenment
That is pledged without ever turning back.
Thus, whatsoever good qualities of generating
The aspirational Mind [of Enlightenment] (bodhicitta)
Have been thoroughly explained by Maitreya
In the Array of Stalks Sūtra.
Read that sūtra or listen to [it from] a Guru, and then
You will have understood that the good qualities of a perfected Mind of Enlightenment
Are limitless. Then, for that very reason,
You should generate this [state of] mind again and again.
The merit of this is demonstrated
In the Sūtra of the Questions of Viradatta;
In this abbreviated [teaching], [I] will write
Merely three stanzas on this [sūtra].
"If whatsoever merit of the Mind of Enlightenment
Existed as a form,
The realm of space would be completely filled, and
That [realm] would be exceeded by that [form].
"If one person were to completely fill with jewels,
Buddhafields — however many equal in number to
The grains of sand in the Ganges river, and
Offer all this to the protector of the world (the Buddha), and
"[Yet] whosoever joins his hands together [in homage],
And orients their mind towards enlightenment,
This offering is superior,
[For] this [offering] has no limit."
Having generated the aspirational Mind of Enlightenment,
Then through much hard work, [you] should constantly enhance [it].
For the sake of remembering this in other lives,
Keep properly, moreover, whatever precepts that were explained.
Without the vow of the engaged Mind of Enlightenment,
There is no increase of the pure aspirations.
Those who desire to increase their aspiration for complete enlightenment,
Because of that, [they] should definitely take up this [practice].
[Only one who] has [one of] the other maintained vows
Of the seven types of Individual Liberation (pratimokṣa) [vows]
Has the good fortune of [taking] the Bodhisattva vow;
It is not otherwise.
Regarding what the Tathagata said in conjunction with
The seven types of Individual Liberation (pratimokṣa) [vows],
The glorious celibate life is supreme.
[This] is asserted as [meaning] the vows of a monk.
In accordance with the ritual stated in the
Ethics Chapter of [Asaṅga’s] Bodhisattva Grounds,
One takes the vow from a good Guru
Who possesses pure character.
One who is skilled in the rituals of the vows,
And remains in [compliance with] whatever vows he has taken,
And has the compassionate forbearance
To impart the vows — know him to be the good Guru.
Thus, if through having made effort,
A guru like this is [still] not found,
I will explain well a ritual other than this
For receiving the vows.
Thus, how did Manjuśrī — in a former life
When he was Ambarāja,
Generate the Exalted Mind of Enlightenment?
As it is told in the sūtra [from the Heap of Jewels collection] called
The Array of Good Qualities of Manjuśrī's Buddha-field,
I write it down here clearly:
"In the presence of the protectors, I generate
The Mind of Perfect Enlightenment,
And invite all sentient beings as my guests,
I will liberate them all from cyclic existence.
"From now on — having held [in the past]
Harmful thoughts, and a mind which is angry,
Miserliness and jealousy,
Until I attain supreme enlightenment, I shall not [permit such thoughts to arise again].
"[I] shall enjoy the celibate life;
And abandon ethical transgression and desire.
Through delighting in the ethical vows,
I shall emulate the Buddha.
"I, myself, am not enthusiastic for obtaining enlightenment
Through the quickest means possible, but rather
I shall remain until the final end
For the sake of [even] a single sentient being.
"I shall thoroughly purify the countless
Inconceivable fields [turning them into Buddha-fields].
And for all those who hold onto me by name,
I shall remain in the ten directions.
"At all [times] purifying
The activities of my body and speech,
I will purify my mind as well, and
Will not engage in non-virtuous actions."
To purify one's body, speech, and mind
Means abiding by one's vows concerning the engaged Mind of Enlightenment.
By being well-trained in the three forms of ethical behavior,
Respect for the three forms of ethical behavior increases.
Hence, through having striven
In the vows which make up the pure and complete
Bodhisattva Vow, the accumulations [necessary]
For complete Enlightenment will be complete.
The cause of the completion of the accumulations —
Whose nature is merit and wisdom,
Is asserted by the all the Buddhas
To be the very generation of the clairvoyances (abhijñā).
Just as a bird whose wings are undeveloped
Is unable fly up into the sky,
Similarly, without the force of clairvoyance,
[One] is not able to accomplish the aims of others.
What are the merits of each day and night
Of possessing the clairvoyances?
One who lacked those clairvoyances,
Would not have it in a hundred lives.
He who wishes to fully perfect
The accumulations of enlightenment that are quickly realized,
He strives hard; it is not through laziness
That one accomplishes the clairvoyances.
Since the clairvoyances will not arise
Without the attainment of calm abiding (śamatha), then
Because of this, in order to achieve calm abiding,
One should strive again and again.
Although one may strive with incomplete parts
Of calm abiding, and although one may meditate,
Years — even thousands [of them] —
Will not bring about the establishment of a meditative stabilization.
Therefore, [when one] is well established in the parts [of calm abiding]
Which are spoken of in [Bodhibhadra’s] Chapter on the Accumulation of Meditative Stabilizations,
One should fix the mind in virtue
On any one object of observation.
When a yogi has achieved calm abiding,
The clairvoyances are achieved as well.
However, without the application of the Perfection of Wisdom
The obstructions will not be exhausted.
Therefore, in order to abandon — without exception,
The afflictive [obstructions] and the obstructions to omniscience,
The yogi should continually cultivate
The Perfection of Wisdom together with Skillful Means.
Wisdom without Skillful Means, and
Skillful Means without Wisdom, as well —
Either of these is called “bondage.”
Therefore, neither should be abandoned.
For the sake of abandoning doubts concerning
What is called “Wisdom” and “Means,”
I shall clarify the difference
Between the Means and Wisdom.
The perfections of giving and so forth,
With the exception of the Perfection of Wisdom —
All these accumulations of virtue
Are explained by the Conquerors (i.e., Buddhas) as Skillfull Means.
Through the force of cultivating Skillful Means, whosoever
By themselves cultivates aspects of Wisdom,
They will quickly attain Enlightenment.
It is not by merely cultivating selflessness.
Knowing the emptiness of inherent existence
Which is realized without the production of
Aggregates, elements, and sense spheres
Is described as "Wisdom."
The production of an [inherently] existent phenomena is not feasible,
Similarly for a non-existent phenomenon like a flower in the sky.
Since there are faulty consequences for both
Neither arise.
A thing is not produced from itself, and
Nor is it from another, or even both.
Since it is not causeless,
It is naturally without inherent existence.
Furthermore, if all phenomena
Are analysed in terms of one or many,
Since an essence is not perceived
They are ascertained as utterly lacking inherent existence.
The reasonings of [Nāgārjuna’s] Seventy Stanzas on Emptiness
And also in the Fundamental Treatise on the Middle Way,
Explain [the manner in which] the emptiness of inherent existence
Of things is established.
Hence, since the scriptures [cited] would be many,
For this [reason, I] have not elaborated [on it], but
I will thoroughly explain it for the sake of meditation
Merely in terms of established tenets.
Therefore, since without exception, an inherent existence
Of any phenomenon is not seen,
Whatever is a meditation on selflessness
Is a cultivation of the Wisdom [realizing] suchness.
In any and all phenomena, this Wisdom
Does not see any inherent existence, and
That same Wisdom is explained through reasoning.
[You] should cultivate this without conceptuality (i.e., non-conceptually).
This transient world which arises out from conceptuality
[Has] a nature which is conceptual.
Thus, abandoning conceptuality without exception
Is the supreme Nirvana.
Moreover, the Transcendent Victor declared:
"Conceptuality is the great ignorance.
[It] casts one into the ocean of cyclic existence.
Abiding in a non-conceptual meditative stabilization,
Non-conceptuality manifests clearly like the sky.
Moreover, it says in the Dhāraṇī of Entry into the Non-conceptual:
"When a son of the Conqueror meditates on
This true Doctrine non-conceptually,
He will transcend these hard to overcome conceptual thoughts, and
Will gradually attain the non-conceptual."
Having ascertained through scripture and reasoning,
The lack of inherent existence and
Lack of production of all phenomena,
Cultivate [the realization] without conceptuality (i.e., non-conceptually).
Thus having meditated on Suchness,
And having gradually attained the "Heat" [Path of Preparation] and so on,
Then one attains [the first Bodhisattva Ground,] the "Joyous" and on;
The Enlightenment of a Buddha [is] not far off.
Through the actions of "Pacification," "Increase," and so forth
Which are established through the power of Mantra,
And also through the power of the Eight Great Accomplishments,
[Such as] the "Good Vessel", and so forth,
One who wishes to perfect
The accumulations of enlightenment through bliss
And if one wants to practice Secret Mantra
As was spoken of in the Tantras of Action, Performance, and so on,
Then, in order [to obtain] the Preceptor-Initiation,
[You] should please a true Guru
In all [ways such as] giving service and veneration,
Precious [things], etc., and undergoing hardships, and so forth.
When, through having pleased the Guru
One receives the complete, perfect Preceptor-Initiation,
Then all [of one's] ethical transgressions have been utterly purified; and
One becomes one of the fortunate who attains all the accomplishments (siddhis).
Because it is emphatically forbidden
In the Great [Kalācakra] Tantra of the Primordial Buddha,
The secret and wisdom initiations
Should not be taken by one who is leading a celibate life.
If [such a one] were to hold this initiation,
Then since [he] abides in the ascetic practices of the celibate life,
It would be a degeneration of his vows of asceticism
Because [he] would be practicing that which is prohibited.
When the infractions arise of one who has been defeated
In his observation of the mode of conduct,
And that [person], by being definite to fall into a bad migration
Will not, moreover, have the accomplishments (siddhis).
Having acquired the Preceptor-Initiation,
[One] can listen to all the tantras, explain [them],
Make burnt offerings, sacrafices, and so on;
There is no fault for [one who] has knowledge about suchness.
I, the Elder (sthavīra), Dīpaṃkāraśrī,
Having seen this explanation in teachings, the sutras, and so forth,
Have made this abbreviated explaination of the Path to Enlightenment
From the request of Jang-chup-ö (byang chub 'od).
This completes the Lamp for the Enlightenment Path that was composed by the great teacher, Dīpaṃkāraśrījñāna.
It was translated and edited by the great Indian abbot himself, and by the great editor and translator Ge-way-lo-drö (dge ba'i blo gros).
The teaching was composed at the To-ling (tho ling) temple in Shang-shung (zhang zhung).
